channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: American Reporter Held by Ukraine Separatists
item.description: The Vice News reporter Simon Ostrovsky, who has produced a series of vivid dispatches from Ukraine in recent weeks, was detained by pro-Russia separatists in the town of Slovyansk on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Nearly 90% of Syria’s Chemical Arms Have Been Removed
item.description: The organization policing Syria’s compliance with a chemical arms ban reported the progress as new allegations surfaced about the use of chlorine bombs.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Abbas Renews Threat to Dissolve Palestinian Authority if Peace Talks Fail
item.description: Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, said that Israel had deprived him of any real power to govern the West Bank and that he was considering giving it back to Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Mourners Vent Rage at Ukrainian Leaders
item.description: At a funeral for three men killed at a checkpoint on Sunday, residents of the pro-Russian city of Slovyansk, Ukraine, held leaders in Kiev responsible for the deaths.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women mourned outside the the Orthodox Church of the Holy Spirit on Tuesday at the funerals of three men killed in a shootout on Sunday.

item.title: Letter From India: Strong Hand Hasn't Fared Well in India
item.description: The desire for a benevolent despot has taken hold among the elites, a sentiment suggesting that Narendra Modi's timing is good.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: The Lede: ‘Nothing Racist’ in Blackface Dancers, English Candidate Insists
item.description: Add dressing up in blackface to perform traditional dances to the ever-growing catalog of behaviors that are not racist according to European politicians.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A Britannia Coconut Dancers commemorative badge.

item.title: Moscow Court Rules Against Navalny in Libel Case
item.description: The ruling against Alexei A. Navalny, a prominent Russian opposition figure, could land him in prison as he awaits trial in another case.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ALEXANDRA ODYNOVA
item.media:description: The ruling on Tuesday against Aleksei A. Navalny, center, which included a fine of about $8,400, may lead to the reinstatement of a suspended sentence from a previous conviction.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 22
item.description: Women cleaning the Dal Lake, in Jammu and Kashmir, on the occasion of Earth Day.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women rowing a boat filled with weeds after cleaning the Dal Lake on the occasion of Earth Day in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir. The day was first observed in the year 1970 at the birth of the modern environmental movement.

item.title: With Sharp Rebuke to Russia, Biden Offers Strong Support to Ukraine
item.description: Offering more aid to Ukraine, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., in Kiev, denounced Russia’s annexing of Crimea, and called on it to help de-escalate the crisis.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke to members of Ukraine's Parliament during a visit to Kiev.

item.title: Reports of Fraud and Violence Temper Joy Over Election in Chaotic Afghan District
item.description: Afghanistan hailed news of high turnout in the Andar district as a triumph for democracy, but interviews with villagers near polling sites offered a stark contrast to the government narrative.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Under Russia, Life in Crimea Grows Chaotic
item.description: A month after the lightning annexation of Crimea, residents find themselves in a state of confusion, with few institutions functioning normally, including banks, courts and foreign businesses.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The line outside the government office in Simferopol, the capital of Crimea, where new Russian passports were being processed.

item.title: Incomes and Outcomes : How Underpaid German Workers Helped Cause Europe’s Debt Crisis
item.description: The stagnation in wages for the German working and middle class was intentional, and is still being felt as European economies struggle to recover.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL IRWIN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Turkey Was Inept, Not Evil, in Syria
item.description: Erdogan’s foreign policy has been characterized more by idealistic delusions than malicious conspiracies.
item.dc:creator: By MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: Search of Suspected Malaysian Jet Crash Site Is Nearly Done
item.description: An exhaustive search in the Indian Ocean has not turned up any debris that can be linked to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: The Bluefin-21, an unmanned submersible, was deployed to search the ocean floor for wreckage from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: Military Analysis: Russia Displays a New Military Prowess in Ukraine’s East
item.description: Russian forces skillfully employed 21st-century tactics that combined cyberwarfare, an energetic information campaign and the use of highly trained special operation troops in its annexation of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Armed men outside an administrative building in Slovyansk, Ukraine. American officials say Russian troops or pro-Russian separatists under Moscow’s influence control such buildings.

item.title: India Ink: Free Education Comes at a Cost for Marginalized Students
item.description: A Human Rights Watch report documents the discrimination at public schools experienced by children in the lowest strata of society in India.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Umesh, a child belonging to the Ghasia community, in Raup village in Uttar Pradesh. “They tied me up and hung me on the window like this,” he said of teacher trainees at the local government school.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: From China, a Video Tribute to Its Aircraft Carrier
item.description: A new music video called “Leading the Dream,” by the state arms manufacturer that refurbished the Liaoning, was released just before the 65th anniversary of the establishment of the People’s Liberation Army Navy.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: India Ink: For British Biographer, Modi Was Only a Phone Call Away
item.description: The only foreigner to have unfettered access to the front-runner in the race for India’s prime minister said it was easy to get Narendra Modi to open up for a biography.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Narendra Modi, left, the front-runner in the race for India's prime minister, with his biographer, Andy Marino.

item.title: North Korea Said to Be Readying Nuclear Test
item.description: The South Korean Defense Ministry said it had “detected various types of activities” at the North Korean site used for previous underground nuclear tests.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U Win Tin, Writer Jailed by Myanmar Junta, Dies
item.description: Mr. Win Tin, who helped found the political party led by the Nobel laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, suffered a harrowing imprisonment.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: U Win Tin, shown in 2010, was imprisoned and tortured for 19 years for his opposition to the military rulers of Myanmar.

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 22
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: A boy wearing a mask of Rahul Gandhi, vice president of the Congress party, at a rally in Mumbai, India, on Sunday.

item.title: Obama’s Strategic Shift to Asia Is Hobbled by Pressure at Home and Crises Abroad
item.description: President Obama is expected to announce an agreement with the Philippines next Monday that would help facilitate a stronger American military presence there, but the deal could antagonize China.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and MARK LANDLER

item.title: Nepalese Government to Set Up Relief Fund for Sherpas
item.description: A day after Sherpas threatened to cancel expeditions up Mount Everest, the government announced that some of the revenue from the treks would be set aside for future aid.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR and BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: Mexico Honors a Colombian Writer Whom Many Considered One of Their Own
item.description: For some writers and admirers, it seemed fitting that the first public memorial service for Gabriel García Márquez took place in Mexico City, where he had lived for many years.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: Musicians performed at a service for Gabriel García Márquez on Monday in the Palace of Fine Arts in Mexico City. Mr. García Márquez was born in Colombia but later moved to Mexico.

item.title: The Lede: Portuguese Drone Program Off to Nonflying Start
item.description: The Portuguese Navy’s fledgling drone program attracted international attention last week because of footage of the failed maiden voyage of a new reconnaissance craft.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
